scenario_1.message: I was thinking about maybe adding a new type of fabric to our shop. But I'm not sure if that's a good idea.
Introducing new fabrics could attract more customers and increase sales, especially if you choose varieties that complement your current stock.
We have always sold the same kinds of cloth. My father taught me these methods, and my brothers do the same. Changing it might upset our regular customers who trust us for quality and familiarity.
Sticking with what works is a solid strategy. You could also consider small trials or limited editions to test customer response without fully committing.

scenario_2.message: Do you think I should send my son to university? He wants to study design, but it’s far from home.
A university education could give him new skills and broaden your shop's offerings. It might also open up business opportunities beyond textiles.
Education is useful, yes, but the trade we have has always been enough for us to live well. My son can learn from me and help keep the family name strong in Alexandria.
Balancing tradition with new knowledge can be beneficial. Perhaps he could study part-time or take short courses while working at the shop.

metadata.demographics: Egyptian man, 41 years old, born in Alexandria. Runs a family-owned textile shop, never left his hometown.
metadata.beliefs: His value states that tradition keeps communities strong, believes children should inherit the family trade, believes neighbours are extended family, believes education is useful but not essential for success, believes stability is more valuable than ambition.
